Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Building a Global Community to Crowdsource-Clean the Planet
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this SBIR Phase I project stems from developing a crowdsourced solution to litter - one of the world's most pervasive and toxic problems. To many, it's dirty, disgusting, and someone else's problem to solve. Unfortunately, we all suffer the consequences, as litter impacts our economy, degrades the environment, demoralizes community pride, kills wildlife, and poisons the food system. This project aims to develop a mobile technology that empowers anyone to identify, map, and collect the world?s litter, while simultaneously connecting to a broader community of associated brands, cities, schools. By crowdsourcing the data and cleanup, there is great potential in collecting massive amounts of information which can be used for everything from infrastructure improvement, to resource allocation, brand packaging redesign, and even individual responsibility and behavioral change.


The intellectual merit of this project is derived from building a global database of litter. And one critical need to achieving such a monumental task is the ability to quickly (and accurately) identify any piece of litter, anytime, anywhere even if the litter is in a deep state of decay and decomposition. This project further aims to integrate that information with other data sets including location, time, proximity to schools, and the watershed. By leveraging technologies such as image recognition and machine learning, the project will further empower the people who are crowdsourcing the data and cleanup to collect a vast amount of identifiable information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Litterati is an environmental intelligence company on a mission to eradicate litter. The company’s technology empowers individuals and groups to “crowdsource-clean” the planet, one piece at a time. What started with one person picking up a single cigarette, has grown into a community of ~100,000, that has identified, mapped, and collected ~2M pieces in 115 countries.

 

Litterati’s mobile application inspires people to photograph and pick up litter. From these photographs, the company’s technology identifies the brand (eg: Starbucks, Marlboro) analyzes the packaging (eg: plastic, styrofoam), and maps problem areas. The company is building a Global Litter Database, powered by a worldwide community.

 

During the Phase I project, Litterati advanced its technology by incorporating machine learning techniques, including image recognition to identify “compromised images” (ie: items in varying states of decay). The company also designed and implemented a litter taxonomy - an automatic classification system which is the first of its kind. These developments grew the Litterati community and increased engagement rates, while attracting new channel partners and paying customers including cities, brands, schools, and non-governmental organizations.

 

Cities, who bare the economic costs of street cleaning, found value in Litterati’s ability to mobilize their citizens and identify the materials and brands most commonly found on their sidewalks, schoolyards, and beaches. The company has already engaged in one pilot, and has built a considerable pipeline of other interested cities. Brands are leveraging the company’s technology for employee engagement programs, as well as a monitoring platform to help understand where their packaging ends up. Schools are integrating Litterati as a citizen-science tool, creating community-service projects and using the collected data in everything from creative writing to social sciences. Environmental groups have adopted Litterati’s technology for coastal cleanups, leveraging the data to monitor marine debris and create brand audits.

 

Ultimately, the power of Litterati lies in the company’s ability to create long-term change. The company’s technology  and crowdsourced data creates awareness and transparency; information that can be used to shape government policy, lead the packaging industry toward more sustainable solutions, and inspire each of us to take greater responsibility for our planet.
